content.introduction: Your credit score is one of the most important financial numbers in your life. It affects your ability to get loans, credit cards, and even rent an apartment.

sections.title: What is a Credit Score?
sections.content: A credit score is a three-digit number that represents your creditworthiness. Scores typically range from 300 to 850, with higher scores indicating better credit.

sections.title: Credit Score Ranges
sections.content:
• Excellent: 750-850
• Good: 700-749
• Fair: 650-699
• Poor: 600-649
• Bad: Below 600

sections.title: Who Creates Credit Scores?
sections.content: The most common credit scores are FICO scores and VantageScore. These are calculated using information from your credit reports from the three major credit bureaus: Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion.

keyTakeaways: Higher scores mean better credit terms
Scores are based on credit report data

title: Factors That Affect Your Credit Score

content.introduction: Understanding what factors influence your credit score is crucial for improving and maintaining good credit.

sections.title: Payment History (35%)
sections.content:
This is the most important factor. It includes:
• On-time payments vs. late payments
• How late payments were
• How recently late payments occurred
• Accounts in collections or charged off

sections.title: Credit Utilization (30%)
sections.content:
This measures how much credit you're using:
• Keep utilization below 30%
• Lower utilization is better
• Both individual and overall utilization matter

sections.title: Length of Credit History (15%)
sections.content:
This includes:
• Age of your oldest account
• Average age of all accounts
• How long since you've used accounts

sections.title: Credit Mix (10%)
sections.content:
Having different types of credit can help:
• Credit cards
• Auto loans
• Mortgages
• Personal loans

sections.title: New Credit (10%)
sections.content:
This factor considers:
• Recent credit inquiries
• Number of new accounts
• Time since last inquiry

keyTakeaways: Don't apply for too much new credit

title: How to Improve Your Credit Score

content.introduction: Improving your credit score takes time and consistent effort, but the benefits are worth it.

sections.title: Pay Bills on Time
sections.content:
• Set up automatic payments
• Use calendar reminders
• Pay at least the minimum amount
• Prioritize credit accounts

sections.title: Reduce Credit Card Balances
sections.content:
• Pay down high balances first
• Consider balance transfer cards
• Make multiple payments per month
• Don't close old accounts

sections.title: Dispute Inaccurate Information
sections.content:
• Review credit reports regularly
• File disputes for errors
• Follow up on dispute responses
• Keep documentation

sections.title: Build Credit History
sections.content:
• Keep old accounts open
• Consider becoming an authorized user
• Use credit cards regularly but responsibly
• Consider a secured credit card if needed

content.introduction: Regular credit monitoring helps you stay on top of changes and catch errors or fraud early.

sections.title: Free Credit Reports
sections.content: You're entitled to one free credit report per year from each bureau at annualcreditreport.com. Consider spacing them out every 4 months.

sections.title: Credit Monitoring Services
sections.content:
Many services offer:
• Monthly credit score updates
• Credit report monitoring
• Fraud alerts
• Identity theft protection

sections.title: What to Look For
sections.content:
When reviewing your reports:
• Personal information accuracy
• Account information
• Payment history
• Accounts you don't recognize
• Inquiries you didn't authorize

keyTakeaways: Act quickly on errors or fraud

content.introduction: Managing debt effectively is crucial for maintaining and improving your credit score.

sections.title: Debt Avalanche Method
sections.content: Focus on paying off debts with the highest interest rates first while making minimum payments on others. This saves the most money in interest.

sections.title: Debt Snowball Method
sections.content: Pay off smallest debts first for psychological wins. While you may pay more interest overall, the motivation can help you stick to the plan.

sections.title: Debt Consolidation
sections.content:
Options include:
• Personal loans
• Balance transfer credit cards
• Home equity loans
• Debt management plans

sections.title: Creating a Budget
sections.content:
Track your income and expenses to find money for debt payments:
• Use the 50/30/20 rule
• Cut unnecessary expenses
• Increase income when possible

keyTakeaways: Choose a debt payoff strategy that works for you
Create and stick to a budget
